Privacy-Aware Compression for Federated Learning Through
Numerical Mechanism Design

Chuan Guo    Kamalika Chaudhuri    Pierre Stock    Mike Rabbat
Abstract

In private federated learning (FL), a server aggregates differentially private updates from a large number of clients in order to train a machine learning model. The main challenge in this setting is balancing privacy with both classification accuracy of the learnt model as well as the number of bits communicated between the clients and server. Prior work has achieved a good trade-off by designing a privacy-aware compression mechanism, called the minimum variance unbiased (MVU) mechanism, that numerically solves an optimization problem to determine the parameters of the mechanism. This paper builds upon it by introducing a new interpolation procedure in the numerical design process that allows for a far more efficient privacy analysis. The result is the new Interpolated MVU mechanism that is more scalable, has a better privacy-utility trade-off, and provides SOTA results on communication-efficient private FL on a variety of datasets.

Machine Learning, ICML

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL; McMahan et al. (2017)) is a distributed solution for machine learning on sensitive data and has been the topic of much recent interest. In federated learning, raw client data resides entirely on the client device, and a server coordinates the collaborative training of a global model through transmissions of model updates. Direct transmission of raw updates (pseudo-gradients) can lead to privacy leaks (Zhu et al., 2019; Geiping et al., 2020; Zhao et al., 2020; Yin et al., 2021; Jeon et al., 2021), and an effective method is to use a rigorous privacy solution such as differential privacy (DP; Dwork et al. (2006)) to transmit privacy-preserving updates. Since federated learning typically involves low-bandwidth clients, a requirement for success is that the amount of communication between the clients and server should be relatively low. Thus a major challenge in this space is ensuring a good privacy-accuracy-communication trade-off—in other words, balancing the predictive accuracy of the model learnt with the privacy parameter as well as the number of bits transmitted between the client and server.

Previous work in this area (Kairouz et al., 2021a; Agarwal et al., 2021; Triastcyn et al., 2021; Chen et al., 2022b) abstracted this problem as privacy-aware compression for distributed mean estimation (DME). Here, the goal is to design a DP mechanism whose output recovers the input in expectation (i.e., is unbiased) and can be represented using a small number of bits. In particular, recent work (Chaudhuri et al., 2022) introduces the minimum variance unbiased (MVU) mechanism, which solves a numerical optimization problem to find the parameters of a mechanism that ensures unbiasedness, privacy and communication efficiency while minimizing the variance of the output. They also experimentally demonstrate that, for a given bit budget, this can lead to better privacy-utility trade-offs than many other methods that independently privatize and then compress.

Unfortunately, a problem with the MVU mechanism (and many other privacy-aware compression mechanisms such as Kairouz et al. (2021a); Agarwal et al. (2021)) is that it does not scale well to high-dimensional vectors. This is a crucial drawback for its application to private FL since model updates are often high-dimensional. A major underlying reason for this drawback is the MVU mechanism’s insistence on unbiasedness. This is achieved using randomized dithering to ensure that the mechanism is unbiased for all continuous-valued inputs, but leads to inefficiencies in the mechanism’s computation and privacy accounting for high-dimensional vectors. Importantly, this drawback is in fact superficial since unbiasedness is not required for FL, and prior work has shown that even crude compressors such as SignSGD (Jin et al., 2020) can perform remarkably well.

In this work, we propose the interpolated MVU (I-MVU) mechanism, which extends MVU using an interpolation procedure that relaxes the unbiasedness assumption. By its discrete nature, the MVU mechanism can be viewed as sampling from a particular categorical distribution, and hence can be expressed in exponential family form. The proposed I-MVU mechanism handles continuous-valued inputs by interpolating the natural exponential family parameters, rather than directly interpolating the probabilities as in dithering. We introduce a new analysis technique, and by further exploiting special properties of the exponential family, we obtain a tight numerical privacy analysis for the vector extension under both L1subscript𝐿1L_{1} and L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} geometry.

Experimentally, we find that under both client-level and sample-level DP settings and across various benchmark datasets, the I-MVU mechanism provides a better privacy-utility trade-off than SignSGD (Jin et al., 2020) and MVU (Chaudhuri et al., 2022) at an extremely low communication budget of one bit per gradient dimension. Moreover, I-MVU achieves close to the same performance as the standard non-compressed Laplace and Gaussian mechanisms (Abadi et al., 2016) for similar levels of (ϵ,δ)\epsilon,\delta)-DP, leading to new state-of-the-art results for private communication-efficient FL.

2 Background

2.1 Differential Privacy

Differential privacy (Dwork et al., 2006) is a cryptographically-motivated definition of privacy that has emerged as the gold standard in privacy-preserving data analysis, and provides rigorous guarantees of privacy leakage induced by a mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M}.

Definition 1 (Differential privacy).

We say that a mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} that applies to datasets 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differentially private, denoted (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP, if for any two neighboring datasets 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime} that differ111We adopt the leave-one-out neighboring notion. in a single individual’s private value, and any output set O𝑂O, we have:

ℙ​(ℳ​(𝒟)∈O)≤eϵ​ℙ​(ℳ​(𝒟′)∈O)+δ.ℙℳ𝒟𝑂superscript𝑒italic-ϵℙℳsuperscript𝒟′𝑂𝛿\mathbb{P}(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})\in O)\leq e^{\epsilon}\mathbb{P}(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})\in O)+\delta.

More generally, the framework of DP seeks to bound the difference in distribution between ℳ​(𝒟)ℳ𝒟\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}) and ℳ​(𝒟′)ℳsuperscript𝒟′\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}) when 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime} differ by a single record that corresponds to one person’s private value. Enforcing this property ensures that a single person’s data does not substantially change the probability of any event that comes out of using the output of the mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M}.

Rényi DP and composition.

A useful variant of DP is Rényi differential privacy (RDP) (Mironov, 2017), which instead bounds the Rényi divergence (Rényi et al., 1961) between ℳ​(𝒟)ℳ𝒟\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}) and ℳ​(𝒟′)ℳsuperscript𝒟′\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}) by some ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon for neighboring datasets 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime} that differ by a single person’s private value. Formally, we say that ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is (α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-RDP if:

max(Dα(ℳ(𝒟)||ℳ(𝒟′)),Dα(ℳ(𝒟′)||ℳ(𝒟)))≤ϵ,\max(D_{\alpha}(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})~{}||~{}\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})),D_{\alpha}(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})~{}||~{}\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})))\leq\epsilon,

where Dαsubscript𝐷𝛼D_{\alpha} denotes the order-α𝛼\alpha Rényi divergence.

An important property of Rényi DP is that it supports easy “sequential composition” of mechanisms—in other words, it makes it relatively simple to measure how the privacy guarantee decays as we release the outputs of multiple differentially private mechanisms on the same dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. Specifically, we have that if ℳ1,…,ℳTsubscriptℳ1…subscriptℳ𝑇\mathcal{M}_{1},\ldots,\mathcal{M}_{T} are mechanisms with ℳtsubscriptℳ𝑡\mathcal{M}_{t} being (α,ϵt)𝛼subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡(\alpha,\epsilon_{t})-RDP for t=1,…,T𝑡1…𝑇t=1,\ldots,T, then the composition of the T𝑇T mechanisms is (α,∑t=1Tϵt)𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡(\alpha,\sum_{t=1}^{T}\epsilon_{t})-RDP. Another useful property of RDP is its conversion to (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP (Balle et al., 2020): If ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is (α,ϵα)𝛼subscriptitalic-ϵ𝛼(\alpha,\epsilon_{\alpha})-RDP for α>1𝛼1\alpha>1 then it is also (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP for any 0<δ<10𝛿10<\delta<1 with

ϵ=ϵα+log⁡(α−1α)−log⁡δ+log⁡αα−1.italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝛼𝛼1𝛼𝛿𝛼𝛼1\epsilon=\epsilon_{\alpha}+\log\left(\frac{\alpha-1}{\alpha}\right)-\frac{\log\delta+\log\alpha}{\alpha-1}. (1)

2.2 Federated Learning with Differential Privacy

Federated learning (FL) (McMahan et al., 2017; Kairouz et al., 2021b) allows distributed training of ML models across multiple clients without centralized data storage. A server coordinates training by acquiring model updates from clients, aggregating them, and then transmitting an updated model back to the clients, and the process repeats until convergence. One promise of FL is data privacy since the updates are computed locally on each client using their own data, and hence no client data is ever explicitly transmitted to the server (or anyone else) throughout training.

In spite of this, a recent line of work showed that it is possible to reconstruct training samples from the model updates in a process called gradient inversion (Zhu et al., 2019; Geiping et al., 2020; Zhao et al., 2020). To truly preserve the privacy of training data in FL, differential privacy (DP; Dwork et al. (2006) can be applied to the model updates (Geyer et al., 2017) to provide provable guarantees against data reconstruction from the its output (Balle et al., 2022; Guo et al., 2022; Stock et al., 2022). To apply DP to FL training, given a DP mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} and a client update 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, the client instead sends ℳ​(𝐱)ℳ𝐱\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{x}) to the server. For a given round, the client’s privacy leakage can be computed in terms of local DP if the privatized update ℳ​(𝐱)ℳ𝐱\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{x}) is revealed to the server, or global DP if secure aggregation (Bonawitz et al., 2017) is applied to aggregate the privatized updates before revealing it to the server. The total privacy leakage throughout training can then be computed via RDP composition and conversion to (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP via Equation 1.

2.3 MVU Mechanism

Privacy-aware compression.

Since model updates in FL are high-dimensional vectors of size equal to the number of model parameters, it is also important in practice to compress these updates for communication efficiency. Prior work studied this privacy-aware compression problem under the abstraction of distributed mean estimation (DME), where clients aim to compute the mean of a set of vectors in a distributed fashion under communication constraint. Formally stated, consider the problem of transmitting a vector 𝐱∈ℝd𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} differentially privately using at most b​d𝑏𝑑bd bits, with b≥1𝑏1b\geq 1 small enough so that the entire vector 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} can be transmitted efficiently. One can reduce this problem to a scalar one by considering how to privately compress x∈[0,1]𝑥01x\in[0,1] using at most b𝑏b bits, and then scaling the vector 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} appropriately and applying the scalar mechanism coordinate-wise.

Scalar MVU.

The minimum variance unbiased (MVU) mechanism (Chaudhuri et al., 2022) solves the privacy-aware compression problem by first discretizing the interval [0,1]01[0,1] into Binsubscript𝐵inB_{\text{in}} points 𝒳={x1=0,x2,…,xBin=1}𝒳formulae-sequencesubscript𝑥10subscript𝑥2…subscript𝑥subscript𝐵in1\mathcal{X}=\{x_{1}=0,x_{2},\ldots,x_{B_{\text{in}}}=1\} with xi:=(i−1)/(Bin−1)assignsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1subscript𝐵in1x_{i}:=(i-1)/(B_{\text{in}}-1). If x=xi𝑥subscript𝑥𝑖x=x_{i}, the mechanism samples j∼Categorical​(𝐩i)similar-to𝑗Categoricalsubscript𝐩𝑖j\sim\text{Categorical}(\mathbf{p}_{i}) using a probability vector 𝐩i∈ΔBout−1subscript𝐩𝑖superscriptΔsubscript𝐵out1\mathbf{p}_{i}\in\Delta^{B_{\text{out}}-1} and outputs ℳ​(x)=aj∈ℝℳ𝑥subscript𝑎𝑗ℝ\mathcal{M}(x)=a_{j}\in\mathbb{R} where {a1,…,aBout}subscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎subscript𝐵out\{a_{1},\ldots,a_{B_{\text{out}}}\} is a pre-determined output alphabet. The probability vectors 𝐩1,…,𝐩Binsubscript𝐩1…subscript𝐩subscript𝐵in\mathbf{p}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{p}_{B_{\text{in}}} and output alphabet {a1,…,aBout}subscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎subscript𝐵out\{a_{1},\ldots,a_{B_{\text{out}}}\} are numerically designed so that the mechanism satisfies the following three properties:

  1. 1.

    ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-differential privacy: e−ϵ​𝐩i′,j≤𝐩i,j≤eϵ​𝐩i′,jsuperscript𝑒italic-ϵsubscript𝐩superscript𝑖′𝑗subscript𝐩𝑖𝑗superscript𝑒italic-ϵsubscript𝐩superscript𝑖′𝑗e^{-\epsilon}\mathbf{p}_{i^{\prime},j}\leq\mathbf{p}_{i,j}\leq e^{\epsilon}\mathbf{p}_{i^{\prime},j} for all i≠i′𝑖superscript𝑖′i\neq i^{\prime} and all j𝑗j.

  2. 2.

    Unbiasedness: ∑j=1Boutaj​𝐩i,j=xisuperscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐵outsubscript𝑎𝑗subscript𝐩𝑖𝑗subscript𝑥𝑖\sum_{j=1}^{B_{\text{out}}}a_{j}\mathbf{p}_{i,j}=x_{i} for all i𝑖i.

  3. 3.

    Minimum variance: ∑i=1BinVar​(ℳ​(xi))superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝐵inVarℳsubscript𝑥𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{B_{\text{in}}}\text{Var}(\mathcal{M}(x_{i})) is minimal among all mechanisms satisfying 1 and 2.

The MVU mechanism can then be applied to all x∈[0,1]𝑥01x\in[0,1] by randomly dithering x𝑥x to the nearest xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} and xi+1subscript𝑥𝑖1x_{i+1} such that the dithering is unbiased in expectation, i.e.,

ℳ​(x)∼{Categorical​(𝐩i)w.p. ​(xi+1−x)/Δ,Categorical​(𝐩i+1)w.p. ​(x−xi)/Δ,similar-toℳ𝑥casesCategoricalsubscript𝐩𝑖w.p. subscript𝑥𝑖1𝑥ΔCategoricalsubscript𝐩𝑖1w.p. 𝑥subscript𝑥𝑖Δ\mathcal{M}(x)\sim\begin{cases}\text{Categorical}(\mathbf{p}_{i})&\text{w.p. }(x_{i+1}-x)/\Delta,\\ \text{Categorical}(\mathbf{p}_{i+1})&\text{w.p. }(x-x_{i})/\Delta,\end{cases}

where Δ=1/(Bin−1)Δ1subscript𝐵in1\Delta=1/(B_{\text{in}}-1). One can also view this dithering procedure as linearly interpolating between 𝐩isubscript𝐩𝑖\mathbf{p}_{i} and 𝐩i+1subscript𝐩𝑖1\mathbf{p}_{i+1}: ℳ​(x)∼Categorical​(𝐩​(x))similar-toℳ𝑥Categorical𝐩𝑥\mathcal{M}(x)\sim\text{Categorical}(\mathbf{p}(x)) with

𝐩​(x)=(xi+1−xΔ)​𝐩i+(x−xiΔ)​𝐩i+1.𝐩𝑥subscript𝑥𝑖1𝑥Δsubscript𝐩𝑖𝑥subscript𝑥𝑖Δsubscript𝐩𝑖1\mathbf{p}(x)=\left(\frac{x_{i+1}-x}{\Delta}\right)\mathbf{p}_{i}+\left(\frac{x-x_{i}}{\Delta}\right)\mathbf{p}_{i+1}. (2)

It is straightforward to generalize the mechanism to any bounded x𝑥x by scaling it to [0,1]01[0,1] and then applying the MVU mechanism.

Vector MVU.

For a d𝑑d-dimensional vector 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, the MVU mechanism can be applied independently to each coordinate and the privacy cost is d​ϵ𝑑italic-ϵd\epsilon by composition if 𝐱∈[0,1]d𝐱superscript01𝑑\mathbf{x}\in[0,1]^{d} (or in general, if ‖𝐱‖∞subscriptnorm𝐱\|\mathbf{x}\|_{\infty} is bounded). The conversion from scalar to vector MVU for privatizing FL updates is more complex since DP training in FL commonly require bounds on ‖𝐱‖1subscriptnorm𝐱1\|\mathbf{x}\|_{1} or ‖𝐱‖2subscriptnorm𝐱2\|\mathbf{x}\|_{2} instead of ‖𝐱‖∞subscriptnorm𝐱\|\mathbf{x}\|_{\infty} (Geyer et al., 2017). To handle these settings, Chaudhuri et al. (2022) proposed an alternative design that replaced property 1 with a metric-DP (Chatzikokolakis et al., 2013) variant: Given a metric d​(x,x′)𝑑𝑥superscript𝑥′d(x,x^{\prime}), the mechanism satisfies

ϵ​-metric-DP: ​e−ϵ​d​(xi,xi′)​𝐩i′,j≤𝐩i,j≤eϵ​d​(xi,xi′)​𝐩i′,jitalic-ϵ-metric-DP: superscript𝑒italic-ϵ𝑑subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥superscript𝑖′subscript𝐩superscript𝑖′𝑗subscript𝐩𝑖𝑗superscript𝑒italic-ϵ𝑑subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥superscript𝑖′subscript𝐩superscript𝑖′𝑗\epsilon\textit{-metric-DP: }e^{-\epsilon d(x_{i},x_{i^{\prime}})}\mathbf{p}_{i^{\prime},j}\leq\mathbf{p}_{i,j}\leq e^{\epsilon d(x_{i},x_{i^{\prime}})}\mathbf{p}_{i^{\prime},j}

for all i≠i′𝑖superscript𝑖′i\neq i^{\prime} and all j𝑗j. Designing MVU with metric-DP property with L1subscript𝐿1L_{1} (resp. L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}) metric allows it to compose more gracefully across dimensions for L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-bounded (resp. L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-bounded) vectors.

3 Interpolated MVU Mechanism

Motivation.

At a high level, distributed mean estimation in general and its application to FL have different considerations and requirements.

  1. 1.

    The unbiasedness requirement in DME is often unnecessary for FL, as the global model does not require a truly unbiased gradient in order to achieve high accuracy.

  2. 2.

    Model updates in FL are typically high-dimensional, which creates issues for the randomized dithering operation used in MVU and other privacy-aware compression mechanisms (Kairouz et al., 2021a; Agarwal et al., 2021). For vectors 𝐱∈ℝd𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, dithering increases ‖𝐱‖1subscriptnorm𝐱1\|\mathbf{x}\|_{1} and ‖𝐱‖2subscriptnorm𝐱2\|\mathbf{x}\|_{2} significantly when d𝑑d is large, hence rejection sampling is needed to control the norm of 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} after dithering. This makes it computationally expensive to apply MVU and causing its privacy accounting to be pessimistic.

Interpolated MVU.

To address these issues, we propose a new interpolation scheme for extending the MVU mechanism to continuous-valued vector inputs. Our new scheme relaxes the unbiasedness requirement in MVU and makes it more suitable for FL use cases. Our first insight is that the categorical distribution used in MVU can be expressed in exponential family form as follows:

ℙ​(j|𝜼)=exp⁡(𝐞j⊤​𝜼−A​(𝜼)),A​(𝜼)=log⁡(∑jexp⁡(𝜼j)),formulae-sequenceℙconditional𝑗𝜼superscriptsubscript𝐞𝑗top𝜼𝐴𝜼𝐴𝜼subscript𝑗subscript𝜼𝑗\mathbb{P}(j|\boldsymbol{\eta})=\exp(\mathbf{e}_{j}^{\top}\boldsymbol{\eta}-A(\boldsymbol{\eta})),\;A(\boldsymbol{\eta})=\log\left(\sum\nolimits_{j}\exp(\boldsymbol{\eta}_{j})\right), (3)

where 𝐞jsubscript𝐞𝑗\mathbf{e}_{j} is the j𝑗j-th standard basis vector. Note that if 𝐩∈ΔBout−1𝐩superscriptΔsubscript𝐵out1\mathbf{p}\in\Delta^{B_{\text{out}}-1} then its natural parameter is 𝜼=log⁡𝐩𝜼𝐩\boldsymbol{\eta}=\log\mathbf{p}.

Expressing the MVU mechanism in exponential family form gives us an alternative way to interpolate the MVU mechanism across the grid points 𝒳={x1,…,xBin}𝒳subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥subscript𝐵in\mathcal{X}=\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{B_{\text{in}}}\}: by interpolating linearly in the natural parameter space. In detail, consider first the scalar setting with input x∈[0,1]𝑥01x\in[0,1]. Let 𝐩1,…,𝐩Bin∈ΔBout−1subscript𝐩1…subscript𝐩subscript𝐵insuperscriptΔsubscript𝐵out1\mathbf{p}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{p}_{B_{\text{in}}}\in\Delta^{B_{\text{out}}-1} be sampling probability vectors obtained from the MVU mechanism and let 𝜼i=log⁡𝐩isubscript𝜼𝑖subscript𝐩𝑖\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}=\log\mathbf{p}_{i} be the natural parameters. Given x∈[0,1]𝑥01x\in[0,1], say x∈[xi,xi+1]𝑥subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1x\in[x_{i},x_{i+1}] for some i𝑖i, the interpolated MVU (I-MVU) mechanism samples j∼ℙ(⋅|𝜼(x))j\sim\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x)) according to Equation 3 and outputs ajsubscript𝑎𝑗a_{j} from the MVU output alphabet, where

𝜼​(x)=(xi+1−xΔ)​𝜼i+(x−xiΔ)​𝜼i+1𝜼𝑥subscript𝑥𝑖1𝑥Δsubscript𝜼𝑖𝑥subscript𝑥𝑖Δsubscript𝜼𝑖1\boldsymbol{\eta}(x)=\left(\frac{x_{i+1}-x}{\Delta}\right)\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}+\left(\frac{x-x_{i}}{\Delta}\right)\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i+1} (4)

and Δ=1/(Bin−1)Δ1subscript𝐵in1\Delta=1/(B_{\text{in}}-1). In other words, instead of linearly interpolating between 𝐩isubscript𝐩𝑖\mathbf{p}_{i} and 𝐩i+1subscript𝐩𝑖1\mathbf{p}_{i+1} as in Equation 2 for the MVU mechanism, we linearly interpolate between the natural parameters 𝜼isubscript𝜼𝑖\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i} and 𝜼i+1subscript𝜼𝑖1\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i+1}.

Controlling bias.

For MVU, because the mechanism is designed so that it is unbiased at all grid points in 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, it is easy to show via Equation 2 and linearity of expectation that it is unbiased for all x∈[0,1]𝑥01x\in[0,1]. This is not true for I-MVU, and interpolating in the natural parameter space incurs some bias when x∉𝒳𝑥𝒳x\notin\mathcal{X}. However, by increasing the number of grid points Binsubscript𝐵inB_{\text{in}}, we can reduce this bias to arbitrarily small with very few drawbacks.

Figure 1 shows the expectation (top) and variance (bottom) of MVU and I-MVU for different values of Bin=2,4,8subscript𝐵in248B_{\text{in}}=2,4,8. The mechanisms are constructed to output b=3𝑏3b=3 bits with target L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-metric-DP ϵ=5italic-ϵ5\epsilon=5. For Bin=2subscript𝐵in2B_{\text{in}}=2, we see that 𝔼​[ℳ​(x)]=x𝔼delimited-[]ℳ𝑥𝑥\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{M}(x)]=x for all x∈[0,1]𝑥01x\in[0,1] for MVU, while the same does not hold for I-MVU. As we increase the number of grid points to Bin=4,8subscript𝐵in48B_{\text{in}}=4,8, the expectation of I-MVU more closely matches that of MVU and the bias tends towards zero. In the bottom plots we show the variance of MVU and I-MVU for different x∈[0,1]𝑥01x\in[0,1] and compare it with that of the Laplace mechanism for the same value of ϵ=5italic-ϵ5\epsilon=5. Notably, for Bin=4,8subscript𝐵in48B_{\text{in}}=4,8, MVU and I-MVU attain comparable variance to that of Laplace while communicating only b=3𝑏3b=3 bits.

3.1 Extensions

Vector I-MVU.

We can extend scalar I-MVU to vector I-MVU by applying the scalar mechanism independently across the vector coordinates. As we will show in subsection 3.2, by utilizing special properties of exponential family distributions, we can more tightly analyze the privacy cost of I-MVU for L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}- and L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-bounded vectors. In addition, because I-MVU does not need to use rejection sampling to control the gradient norm after randomized dithering, privatizing the input simply amounts to sampling a single categorical random variable per coordinate and is much more computationally efficient.

Input scaling. One way to extend I-MVU to arbitrary bounded ranges is to first scale the input to [0,1]01[0,1] and then apply the mechanism as usual. However, note that the interpolation scheme in Equation 4 is in fact well-defined for any x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}, and hence the scaled input does not need to be strictly in the range [0,1]01[0,1]. We leverage this property by introducing a scaling factor β≥0𝛽0\beta\geq 0 as follows. For u∈[−C,C]𝑢𝐶𝐶u\in[-C,C], the β𝛽\beta-scaled I-MVU mechanism is defined as:

ℳβ​(u)=ℳ​(12+β​u2​C),subscriptℳ𝛽𝑢ℳ12𝛽𝑢2𝐶\mathcal{M}_{\beta}(u)=\mathcal{M}\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\beta u}{2C}\right),

where ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is the plain I-MVU mechanism. Note that this scaling effectively ensures that the input to ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is in the range [(1−β)/2,(1+β)/2]1𝛽21𝛽2\left[(1-\beta)/2,(1+\beta)/2\right], with β=1𝛽1\beta=1 corresponding to scaling the input to [0,1]01[0,1]. For vectors 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u} with ‖𝐮‖2≤Csubscriptnorm𝐮2𝐶\|\mathbf{u}\|_{2}\leq C, the β𝛽\beta-scaled input 𝐱=12+β​𝐮2​C𝐱12𝛽𝐮2𝐶\mathbf{x}=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\beta\mathbf{u}}{2C} satisfies ‖𝐱‖2≤β/2subscriptnorm𝐱2𝛽2\|\mathbf{x}\|_{2}\leq\beta/2.

One advantage for using β𝛽\beta-scaling is that if the distribution of u𝑢u is highly concentrated near zero, then scaling with β>1𝛽1\beta>1 ensures that the input to ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is more spread out in the range [0,1]01[0,1]. Because the MVU mechanism is designed to minimize the average variance across the range [0,1]01[0,1] (property 3), doing so allows us to better utilize its minimum variance property. For L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}- and L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-bounded vectors 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u} this is especially true, where the distribution of coordinates of 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u} is likely concentrated near zero, hence β𝛽\beta-scaling with a large β𝛽\beta is essential for achieving good performance.

3.2 Privacy Analysis

We analyze privacy leakage of the I-MVU mechanism in terms of both pure DP and Rényi DP (Mironov, 2017). We first present a general analysis for the I-MVU mechanism with any Bin≥1subscript𝐵in1B_{\text{in}}\geq 1 applied to L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-bounded vectors in Theorem 1. Then we give a more specialized analysis for I-MVU with Bin=2subscript𝐵in2B_{\text{in}}=2 applied to L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-bounded vectors in Theorem 2. Proofs of theorems and lemmas are given in Appendix A.

L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-bounded vector analysis.

Our strategy is to first analyze the scalar mechanism and express its max divergence for two differing inputs x𝑥x and x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} as a function of |x′−x|superscript𝑥′𝑥|x^{\prime}-x| (Lemma 1). Then, by independently applying the mechanism across coordinates, we can sum the max divergence across coordinates and upper bound the total DP ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon as a function of ‖𝐱′−𝐱‖1subscriptnormsuperscript𝐱′𝐱1\|\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{x}\|_{1} (Theorem 1).

Lemma 1.

Suppose x,x′∈[0,1]𝑥superscript𝑥′01x,x^{\prime}\in[0,1] and the MVU mechanism satisfies ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-metric-DP. Let ϵ′=(Bin−1)×(maxi⁡maxξ∈[xi,xi+1]⁡|σ​(𝛈​(ξ))⊤​(𝛈i+1−𝛈i)|)superscriptitalic-ϵ′subscript𝐵in1subscript𝑖subscript𝜉subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1𝜎superscript𝛈𝜉topsubscript𝛈𝑖1subscript𝛈𝑖\epsilon^{\prime}=(B_{\text{in}}-1)\times(\max_{i}\max_{\xi\in[x_{i},x_{i+1}]}|\sigma(\boldsymbol{\eta}(\xi))^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i+1}-\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i})|). Then:

D∞(ℙ(⋅|𝜼(x))||ℙ(⋅|𝜼(x′)))≤(ϵ+ϵ′)|x′−x|.D_{\infty}(\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x))~{}||~{}\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x^{\prime})))\leq(\epsilon+\epsilon^{\prime})|x^{\prime}-x|.
Theorem 1.

Let ϵ′superscriptitalic-ϵ′\epsilon^{\prime} be the constant from Lemma 1. Suppose the MVU mechanism is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-metric-DP and that 𝐱,𝐱′∈ℝd𝐱superscript𝐱′superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} satisfy ‖𝐱′−𝐱‖1≤Csubscriptnormsuperscript𝐱′𝐱1𝐶\|\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{x}\|_{1}\leq C, then the I-MVU mechanism is (ϵ+ϵ′)​Citalic-ϵsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′𝐶(\epsilon+\epsilon^{\prime})C-DP.

The constant ϵ′superscriptitalic-ϵ′\epsilon^{\prime} can be computed numerically by maximizing the function h​(ξ)=|σ​(𝜼​(ξ))⊤​(𝜼i+1−𝜼i)|ℎ𝜉𝜎superscript𝜼𝜉topsubscript𝜼𝑖1subscript𝜼𝑖h(\xi)=|\sigma(\boldsymbol{\eta}(\xi))^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i+1}-\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i})| over the range ξ∈[xi,xi+1]𝜉subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1\xi\in[x_{i},x_{i+1}] for every i𝑖i.

L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-bounded vector analysis.

Our privacy analysis for L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-bounded vectors follows a similar strategy, but instead depends on a measure of information known as Fisher information, which we define below for completeness. Intuitively, Fisher information measures the curvature of the Rényi divergence, i.e., the rate of change of divergence with respect to input x𝑥x.

Definition 2.

Let f𝑓f be the density function of a distribution parameterized by x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}. The Fisher information of x𝑥x contained in a sample Z∼f(⋅|x)Z\sim f(\cdot|x) is:

ℐZ​(x):=𝔼Z​[(dd​x​log⁡f​(Z|x))2].assignsubscriptℐ𝑍𝑥subscript𝔼𝑍delimited-[]superscript𝑑𝑑𝑥𝑓conditional𝑍𝑥2\mathcal{I}_{Z}(x):=\mathbb{E}_{Z}\left[\left(\frac{d}{dx}\log f(Z|x)\right)^{2}\right]. (5)

In our setting, the distribution ℙ(⋅|𝜼(x))\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x)) is defined by the private data x𝑥x, and Fisher information measures how much information is revealed about x𝑥x through a sample j∼ℙ(⋅|𝜼(x))j\sim\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x)). It is noteworthy that such a reasoning has also been used to define Fisher information as a privacy metric (Hannun et al., 2021).

For Fisher information to be well-defined, it is necessary that the distribution has a differentiable log density function. For the I-MVU interpolation scheme this is only true if Bin=2subscript𝐵in2B_{\text{in}}=2; otherwise, the log density may be non-differentiable when transitioning from an interval [xi−1,xi]subscript𝑥𝑖1subscript𝑥𝑖[x_{i-1},x_{i}] to [xi,xi+1]subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1[x_{i},x_{i+1}]. Thus, Lemma 2 and Theorem 2 below are specialized to Bin=2subscript𝐵in2B_{\text{in}}=2, which we find is sufficient for most FL applications with L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-bounded vectors.

Lemma 2.

Let Bin=2subscript𝐵in2B_{\text{in}}=2 and let M=supx∈ℝℐZ​(x)𝑀subscriptsupremum𝑥ℝsubscriptℐ𝑍𝑥M=\sup_{x\in\mathbb{R}}\mathcal{I}_{Z}(x) be an upper bound on the Fisher information of the mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M}. Then for any x1,x2∈ℝsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2ℝx_{1},x_{2}\in\mathbb{R}:

Dα(ℙ(⋅|𝜼(x1))||ℙ(⋅|𝜼(x2)))≤αM(x2−x1)2/2.D_{\alpha}(\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x_{1}))~{}||~{}\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x_{2})))\leq\alpha M(x_{2}-x_{1})^{2}/2. (6)

Applying Lemma 2 in a similar manner as in the L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-bounded case by summing the Rényi divergence across coordinates as a function of ‖𝐱′−𝐱‖22superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝐱′𝐱22\|\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{x}\|_{2}^{2} yields Theorem 2.

Theorem 2.

Let Bin=2subscript𝐵in2B_{\text{in}}=2 and let M𝑀M be the Fisher information constant from Lemma 2. Suppose that 𝐱1,𝐱2∈ℝdsubscript𝐱1subscript𝐱2superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}_{1},\mathbf{x}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} satisfy ‖𝐱2−𝐱1‖2≤Csubscriptnormsubscript𝐱2subscript𝐱12𝐶\|\mathbf{x}_{2}-\mathbf{x}_{1}\|_{2}\leq C. Then the I-MVU mechanism is (α,α​M​C2/2)𝛼𝛼𝑀superscript𝐶22(\alpha,\alpha MC^{2}/2)-RDP for all α>1𝛼1\alpha>1.

Proof sketch. We first derive the Taylor series expression for the Rényi divergence between ℙ(⋅|𝜼(x1))\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x_{1})) and ℙ(⋅|𝜼(x2))\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x_{2})). Since Rényi divergence is minimized and is equal to 00 when x1=x2subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2x_{1}=x_{2}, the zeroth-order and first-order terms in the Taylor series are 00. The coefficient for the second-order term is given by the Fisher information ℐZ​(x1)subscriptℐ𝑍subscript𝑥1\mathcal{I}_{Z}(x_{1}) (Haussler & Opper, 1997), and thus we give a numerical method to compute M=supx∈ℝℐZ​(x)𝑀subscriptsupremum𝑥ℝsubscriptℐ𝑍𝑥M=\sup_{x\in\mathbb{R}}\mathcal{I}_{Z}(x) in Appendix B and use it in Equation 6 to bound the RDP ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.

4 Experiments

We evaluate the I-MVU mechanism for federated learning under the local DP setting, i.e., clients transmit the privately compressed model update ℳ​(𝐱)ℳ𝐱\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{x}) to the server before aggregation. We consider two different notions of adjacency for DP: client-level, where adjacency is defined as removal of any client, and sample-level, where adjacency is defined as removal of a single sample at one client.

Baselines.

We compare I-MVU with several privacy-aware compression mechanisms that have been proposed for private FL training:

  1. 1.

    MVU mechanism (Chaudhuri et al., 2022) for L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-bounded client updates.

  2. 2.

    Skellam mechanism (Agarwal et al., 2021), which discretizes the input using randomized dithering and adds noise from the Skellam distribution to achieve privacy-aware compression of L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-bounded client updates.

  3. 3.

    SignSGD (Jin et al., 2020) is a strong simple baseline that first applies a non-compressed DP mechanism to the gradient and then transmits its sign coordinate-wise. Since it operates as a post-processing step on top of a non-compressed DP mechanism, it inherits the privacy guarantee of the non-compressed mechanism while only outputting one bit per parameter. We evaluate SignSGD with both Laplace and Gaussian mechanisms for L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-bounded and L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-bounded client updates.

  4. 4.

    Laplace and Gaussian mechanisms serve as the non-compressed baselines for L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-bounded and L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-bounded client updates. We transmit the private updates using floating point with 32 bits per parameter.

A good privacy-aware compression mechanism should achieve a desirable privacy-utility trade-off (i.e., high test accuracy with low DP ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon) while transmitting the client updates in a communication-efficient manner. Since our application domain is FL, we did not consider many generic DP distributed mean estimation mechanisms such as PrivUnit (Bhowmick et al., 2018) and Poisson binomial mechanism (Chen et al., 2022b). These mechanisms are designed primarily for privately compressing low-dimensional vectors in an unbiased manner; in contrast, model updates in FL are high-dimensional L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-bounded vectors and do not need to be unbiased.

4.1 Client-level DP

We first evaluate under the client-level DP setting on MNIST and CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009). Here, the privacy analysis guarantees that the learning algorithm is differentially private with respect to the removal of any client. We divide the training set among the clients with client sample size 1. Each client performs a single local gradient update in every FL round. This setting is equivalent to DP-SGD training (Abadi et al., 2016) but with the Gaussian mechanism replaced by a communication-efficient private mechanism.

Training details. Following (Chaudhuri et al., 2022), we train a linear model on top of ScatterNet features (Tramer & Boneh, 2020). This training recipe remains highly competitive under the central DP setting for MNIST and CIFAR-10 without leveraging any public data, hence we adopt it for FL training under local DP. Following Abadi et al. (2016), we apply L1subscript𝐿1L_{1} and L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} gradient norm clipping to control the gradient sensitivity and then apply a privacy-aware compression mechanism to transmit the clipped gradient privately. We perform a grid search over hyperparameters such as number of update rounds, step size, gradient norm clip, and mechanism parameters σ𝜎\sigma (for Gaussian and SignSGD) and ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon (for MVU and I-MVU); see Appendix C for details.

Result for L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-bounded client updates. We first consider the more common approach of L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-norm clipping. Figure 2 shows the privacy vs. test accuracy curve on MNIST (left) and CIFAR-10 (right). Privacy is measured in terms of (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP at δ=10−5𝛿superscript105\delta=10^{-5}. For each hyperparameter setting, we compute the average test accuracy over five training runs to produce a single ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-accuracy pair, and plot the Pareto frontier as a dotted line. The yellow line corresponds to the standard Gaussian mechanism without compression, which attains the best test accuracy at any given privacy budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Both SignSGD and MVU are competitive, achieving close to the same level of accuracy as the Gaussian mechanism, but a non-negligible gap remains, especially on CIFAR-10. In contrast, I-MVU attains nearly the same performance as the Gaussian mechanism at all values of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon on both MNIST and CIFAR-10. Since MVU and I-MVU are near-identical mechanisms, we argue that the performance gain comes primarily from the tight privacy analysis for L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} geometry using Fisher information (Section 3.2).

In Figure 3 we repeat the experiment with an ImageNet pre-trained WideResNet-28-10 (Zagoruyko & Komodakis, 2016) model. The model is pre-trained on down-scaled 32×32323232\times 32 resolution ImageNet (Deng et al., 2009) samples and then finetuned on CIFAR-10 using either the Gaussian mechanism, signSGD or I-MVU. We did not apply the MVU or Skellam mechanisms because the dithering operation is prohibitively expensive on such a large model. We observe a similar result where I-MVU matches the performance of the Gaussian mechanism across the board.

Result for L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-bounded client updates. For completeness, we also show the result for compressing updates with L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-norm clipping. This approach is uncommon in private FL training as the noise variance is much larger, but can provide an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-DP guarantee as opposed to (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP with L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-norm clipping. Figure 4 shows the privacy (in terms of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-DP) vs. test accuracy Pareto frontier curve on MNIST (left) and CIFAR-10 (right). It can be seen that I-MVU with b=4𝑏4b=4 attains almost the same privacy-utility trade-off as the non-compressed Laplace mechanism, while I-MVU with lower b𝑏b attain a worse trade-off. Surprisingly, SignSGD outperforms both Laplace and I-MVU with a communication budget of b=1𝑏1b=1. We suspect this is due to the inherent variance reduction effect of sign compression and that FL training does not require the gradient to be unbiased.

4.2 Sample-level DP

Next, we evaluate under the sample-level DP setting on the FEMNIST dataset (Caldas et al., 2018) for classifying written characters into 62 distinct classes. Privacy analysis guarantees that the learning algorithm is differentially private with respect to the removal of any training sample from a client. The dataset has a pre-defined train split with 3,50035003,500 clients, from which we randomly select 3,15031503,150 clients for training and the remaining 350350350 clients for testing. A set of 555 clients is selected in each training round. Each client performs full batch gradient descent for a single local gradient update to compute the update vector. The update vector is privatized using a communication-efficient private mechanism and transmitted to the server.

Training details. We train a simple 4-layer convolutional network with 46k parameters for classification. The model achieves 84%percent8484\% accuracy when trained non-privately with FL. The client optimizer is SGD with a learning rate of 0.10.10.1 and no momentum. The server implements FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017) with a momentum of 0.90.90.9. We perform a grid search on the server learning rate, the clipping factor, the noise multiplier σ𝜎\sigma for Gaussian and SignSGD, noise scale μ𝜇\mu for Skellam, and the L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-metric DP ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and scale hyperparameters for I-MVU. The hyperparameter ranges are given in Tables 5, 4 and 6 in the appendix. In particular, SignSGD uses a much lower server-side learning rates since the updates (in {±1}plus-or-minus1\{\pm 1\}) have higher magnitude.

Result. We show the privacy-accuracy trade-off for FEMNIST in Figure 5. The Pareto frontier represents the optimal privacy-accuracy trade-off. The DP privacy budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is given at δ=10−5𝛿superscript105\delta=10^{-5}. We observe that I-MVU (blue dashed line) performs better than SignSGD (silver dashed line) for the same communication budget of one bit per update coordinate across the entire range of considered privacy budgets ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Moreover, I-MVU performs on par with the non-compressed Gaussian baseline (yellow dashed line), where clients perform local DP-SGD without compressing model updates. I-MVU also outperforms the Skellam mechanism (green dashed line) using 16 times less bandwidth. Additionally, to demonstrate the performance of I-MVU across a wider bit range, we display the performance of the proposed method for various communication budgets in Figure 6.

5 Related Work

Privacy-aware compression.

The problem of privacy-aware compression for distributed mean estimation (DME) has received much attention in recent years. Prior work proposed notable mechanisms such as PrivUnit (Bhowmick et al., 2018; Asi et al., 2022), discrete Gaussian (Canonne et al., 2020; Kairouz et al., 2021a), Skellam (Agarwal et al., 2021), MVU (Chaudhuri et al., 2022) and others (Chen et al., 2020; Girgis et al., 2021; Shah et al., 2022; Chen et al., 2022b; Lang & Shlezinger, 2022) for computing the mean of a set of vectors under communication constraint. Feldman & Talwar (2021) provides a general procedure for converting a non-compressed mechanism to a compressed one that is computationally differentially private under the assumption that the pseudo-random generator in the privacy mechanism is hard to break.

There are also other approaches for privacy-aware compression in FL that do not rely on solving the DME problem. For example, Jin et al. (2020) first showed that a simple post-processing of non-compressed mechanisms by taking the sign is a strong baseline that does not attain unbiasedness but works well in practice. Other mechanisms such as DP-REC (Triastcyn et al., 2021) have also leveraged special properties of FL to design more efficient privacy-aware compression schemes for transmitting model updates.

Non-private compression in FL.

Previous work has also studied non-private compression in FL, with a focus on characterizing how noise due to (lossy) compression impacts optimization dynamics. Methods have been proposed to only compress up-link (from client to server) messages (Basu et al., 2019; Reisizadeh et al., 2020; Albasyoni et al., 2020; Haddadpour et al., 2021; Mitra et al., 2021; Sadiev et al., 2022), as well as both up- and down-link messages (Philippenko & Dieuleveut, 2020; Condat et al., 2022). Although none of these provides privacy, they do illustrate that federated training is possible with biased compression methods. Note that, in private FL, the downlink messages can be considered non-private, so only the uplink would need to make use of privacy-aware compression.

Mechanism design through optimization.

Classical DP mechanisms are mostly derived from simple parameterized distributions and whose privacy is analyzed mathematically. For more specialized applications such as FL where the requirements are complex, it is often helpful to design custom mechanisms by optimizing a certain objective under DP constraints. Geng et al. (2015) proposed the staircase mechanism and showed that it is variance-optimal in the low-to-medium privacy regime for privatizing L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-bounded vectors. Bhowmick et al. (2018); Asi et al. (2022) proposed the PrivUnit mechanism and its variant PrivUnitG that are variance-optimal for privatizing unit L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} vectors under a communication constraint. More similar to our work, Bordenabe et al. (2014) designed an optimal mechanism for location privacy by numerically solving a linear program.

6 Conclusion

We proposed the Interpolated MVU (I-MVU) mechanism that drastically reduces the amount of uplink communication in cross-device FL while providing differential privacy guarantees. I-MVU can be readily applied to DP training of FL models with L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}- and L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-bounded vectors, with performing matching that of the Laplace and Gaussian mechanisms while communicating as few as one bit per parameter.

Limitations.

We discuss several limitations of I-MVU and suggest potential directions for future work.

1. The mechanism currently operates under the local DP setting, which does not leverage the power of secure aggregation to further reduce the privacy cost. Since I-MVU outputs samples from the categorical distribution, their sum forms a so-called Poisson multinomial distribution, whose properties need to be analyzed to understand the privacy cost of I-MVU under the central DP setting.

2. Our work focused on extending MVU through better interpolation and privacy analysis and did not modify the underlying mechanism design problem. Choices such as the set of grid points 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, variance objective, and DP constraint can be adapted to better leverage the structure of the new interpolation scheme.

3. Our scalar-to-vector extension of I-MVU can achieve at best a one bit per parameter compression rate. Compressing further to below one bit per parameter may be necessary for applications of FL to large-scale models. Combining I-MVU with recent work on sketching-based compression (Chen et al., 2022a) can be a promising solution.

|logℙ(j|𝜼(x))−logℙ(j|𝜼(x′))|\displaystyle|\log\mathbb{P}(j|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x))-\log\mathbb{P}(j|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x^{\prime}))| =|(x′−xΔ)​𝐞j⊤​𝜼i+(x−x′Δ)​𝐞j⊤​𝜼i+1−A​(𝜼​(x))+A​(𝜼​(x′))|absentsuperscript𝑥′𝑥Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐞𝑗topsubscript𝜼𝑖𝑥superscript𝑥′Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐞𝑗topsubscript𝜼𝑖1𝐴𝜼𝑥𝐴𝜼superscript𝑥′\displaystyle=\left|\left(\frac{x^{\prime}-x}{\Delta}\right)\mathbf{e}_{j}^{\top}\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}+\left(\frac{x-x^{\prime}}{\Delta}\right)\mathbf{e}_{j}^{\top}\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i+1}-A(\boldsymbol{\eta}(x))+A(\boldsymbol{\eta}(x^{\prime}))\right|

Theorem 1.

Let ϵ′superscriptitalic-ϵ′\epsilon^{\prime} be the constant from Lemma 1. Suppose the MVU mechanism is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-metric-DP and that 𝐱,𝐱′∈ℝd𝐱superscript𝐱′superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} satisfy ‖𝐱′−𝐱‖1≤Csubscriptnormsuperscript𝐱′𝐱1𝐶\|\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{x}\|_{1}\leq C, then the I-MVU mechanism is (ϵ+ϵ′)​Citalic-ϵsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′𝐶(\epsilon+\epsilon^{\prime})C-DP.

Proof.

Let 𝐚=ℳ​(𝐱)∈{a1,…,aBout}d𝐚ℳ𝐱superscriptsubscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎subscript𝐵out𝑑\mathbf{a}=\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{x})\in\{a_{1},\ldots,a_{B_{\text{out}}}\}^{d} be the output of the vector I-MVU mechanism that independently applies the scalar mechanism to each coordinate. Then:

D∞(ℳ(𝐱)||ℳ(𝐱′))\displaystyle D_{\infty}(\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{x})~{}||~{}\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{x}^{\prime})) =max𝐚∈{a1,…,aBout}d|∑k=1dlogℙ(𝐚k|𝜼(𝐱k′))−∑k=1dlogℙ(𝐚k|𝜼(𝐱k))|\displaystyle=\max_{\mathbf{a}\in\{a_{1},\ldots,a_{B_{\text{out}}}\}^{d}}\left|\sum_{k=1}^{d}\log\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{a}_{k}|\boldsymbol{\eta}(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}_{k}))-\sum_{k=1}^{d}\log\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{a}_{k}|\boldsymbol{\eta}(\mathbf{x}_{k}))\right|
≤∑k=1dmax𝐚k∈{a1,…,aBout}|logℙ(𝐚k|𝜼(𝐱k′))−logℙ(𝐚k|𝜼(𝐱k))|\displaystyle\leq\sum_{k=1}^{d}\max_{\mathbf{a}_{k}\in\{a_{1},\ldots,a_{B_{\text{out}}}\}}\left|\log\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{a}_{k}|\boldsymbol{\eta}(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}_{k}))-\log\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{a}_{k}|\boldsymbol{\eta}(\mathbf{x}_{k}))\right|
=∑k=1dD∞(ℙ(⋅|𝜼(𝐱k))||ℙ(⋅|𝜼(𝐱k′)))\displaystyle=\sum_{k=1}^{d}D_{\infty}(\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(\mathbf{x}_{k}))~{}||~{}\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}_{k})))
≤∑k=1dΔ~​(𝜼)​|𝐱k′−𝐱k|by Lemma 1absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑑~Δ𝜼subscriptsuperscript𝐱′𝑘subscript𝐱𝑘by Lemma 1\displaystyle\leq\sum_{k=1}^{d}\tilde{\Delta}(\boldsymbol{\eta})|\mathbf{x}^{\prime}_{k}-\mathbf{x}_{k}|\quad\text{by Lemma \ref{lem:dp_scalar}}
=Δ~​(𝜼)​‖𝐱′−𝐱‖1.absent~Δ𝜼subscriptnormsuperscript𝐱′𝐱1\displaystyle=\tilde{\Delta}(\boldsymbol{\eta})\|\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{x}\|_{1}.

∎

Lemma 2.

Let Bin=2subscript𝐵in2B_{\text{in}}=2 and let M=supx∈ℝℐZ​(x)𝑀subscriptsupremum𝑥ℝsubscriptℐ𝑍𝑥M=\sup_{x\in\mathbb{R}}\mathcal{I}_{Z}(x) be an upper bound on the Fisher information of the mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M}. Then for any x,x′∈ℝ𝑥superscript𝑥′ℝx,x^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}:

Dα(ℙ(⋅|𝜼(x))||ℙ(⋅|𝜼(x′)))≤αM(x′−x)2/2.D_{\alpha}(\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x))~{}||~{}\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x^{\prime})))\leq\alpha M(x^{\prime}-x)^{2}/2.
Proof.

We first derive an explicit form for the Fisher information. Let f​(𝐳;x)𝑓𝐳𝑥f(\mathbf{z};x) denote the pmf in Equation 3 for any 𝐳∈{𝐞1,…,𝐞Bout}𝐳subscript𝐞1…subscript𝐞subscript𝐵out\mathbf{z}\in\{\mathbf{e}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{e}_{B_{\text{out}}}\}. The log pmf is:

log⁡f​(𝐳;x)=𝐳⊤​𝜼​(x)−A​(𝜼​(x))𝑓𝐳𝑥superscript𝐳top𝜼𝑥𝐴𝜼𝑥\log f(\mathbf{z};x)=\mathbf{z}^{\top}\boldsymbol{\eta}(x)-A(\boldsymbol{\eta}(x)) (8)

Taking derivative with respect to x𝑥x gives:

Appendix B Computing Fisher Information

In this section we describe a method for computing M=supx∈ℝℐZ​(x)𝑀subscriptsupremum𝑥ℝsubscriptℐ𝑍𝑥M=\sup_{x\in\mathbb{R}}\mathcal{I}_{Z}(x). We first define a condition for 𝜼1,𝜼2subscript𝜼1subscript𝜼2\boldsymbol{\eta}_{1},\boldsymbol{\eta}_{2} that allows us to reduce this problem to maximizing ℐZ​(x)subscriptℐ𝑍𝑥\mathcal{I}_{Z}(x) over a bounded range [xmin,xmax]subscript𝑥subscript𝑥[x_{\min},x_{\max}].

Definition 3.

Two vectors 𝛈1,𝛈2∈ℝBsubscript𝛈1subscript𝛈2superscriptℝ𝐵\boldsymbol{\eta}_{1},\boldsymbol{\eta}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{B} are said to be anadromic if for all j=1,…,B𝑗1…𝐵j=1,\ldots,B, we have (𝛈1)j=(𝛈2)B−j+1subscriptsubscript𝛈1𝑗subscriptsubscript𝛈2𝐵𝑗1(\boldsymbol{\eta}_{1})_{j}=(\boldsymbol{\eta}_{2})_{B-j+1}.

The following technical lemma proves several useful properties that hold when 𝜼1subscript𝜼1\boldsymbol{\eta}_{1} and 𝜼2subscript𝜼2\boldsymbol{\eta}_{2} are anadromic.

Lemma 3.

Suppose that 𝛈1,𝛈2∈ℝBsubscript𝛈1subscript𝛈2superscriptℝ𝐵\boldsymbol{\eta}_{1},\boldsymbol{\eta}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{B} are anadromic. Let 𝛉=𝛈2−𝛈1𝛉subscript𝛈2subscript𝛈1\boldsymbol{\theta}=\boldsymbol{\eta}_{2}-\boldsymbol{\eta}_{1} and suppose that j+=arg​maxj⁡𝛉j,j−=arg​minj⁡𝛉jformulae-sequencesuperscript𝑗subscriptargmax𝑗subscript𝛉𝑗superscript𝑗subscriptargmin𝑗subscript𝛉𝑗j^{+}=\operatorname*{arg\,max}_{j}\boldsymbol{\theta}_{j},j^{-}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{j}\boldsymbol{\theta}_{j} are unique. Then the following hold:

  1. (i)

    𝜽j=−𝜽B−j+1subscript𝜽𝑗subscript𝜽𝐵𝑗1\boldsymbol{\theta}_{j}=-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{B-j+1} for all j𝑗j, and hence j−=B−j++1superscript𝑗𝐵superscript𝑗1j^{-}=B-j^{+}+1.

  2. (ii)

    𝜼​(x)j=𝜼​(1−x)B−j+1𝜼subscript𝑥𝑗𝜼subscript1𝑥𝐵𝑗1\boldsymbol{\eta}(x)_{j}=\boldsymbol{\eta}(1-x)_{B-j+1} for all j𝑗j.

  3. (iii)

    σ​(𝜼​(x))→𝐞j+→𝜎𝜼𝑥subscript𝐞superscript𝑗\sigma(\boldsymbol{\eta}(x))\rightarrow\mathbf{e}_{j^{+}} as x→∞→𝑥x\rightarrow\infty and σ​(𝜼​(x))→𝐞j−→𝜎𝜼𝑥subscript𝐞superscript𝑗\sigma(\boldsymbol{\eta}(x))\rightarrow\mathbf{e}_{j^{-}} as x→−∞→𝑥x\rightarrow-\infty.

  4. (iv)

    ℐZ​(x)=ℐZ​(1−x)subscriptℐ𝑍𝑥subscriptℐ𝑍1𝑥\mathcal{I}_{Z}(x)=\mathcal{I}_{Z}(1-x) for all x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}.

  5. (v)

    x=1/2𝑥12x=1/2 is a stationary point for ℐZ​(x)subscriptℐ𝑍𝑥\mathcal{I}_{Z}(x).

  6. (vi)

    If σ​(𝜼​(x))j+≥1/2𝜎subscript𝜼𝑥superscript𝑗12\sigma(\boldsymbol{\eta}(x))_{j^{+}}\geq 1/2 then ℐZ​(x)≤4​𝜽j+2​σ​(𝜼​(x))j+​(1−σ​(𝜼​(x))j+)subscriptℐ𝑍𝑥4superscriptsubscript𝜽superscript𝑗2𝜎subscript𝜼𝑥superscript𝑗1𝜎subscript𝜼𝑥superscript𝑗\mathcal{I}_{Z}(x)\leq 4\boldsymbol{\theta}_{j^{+}}^{2}\sigma(\boldsymbol{\eta}(x))_{j^{+}}(1-\sigma(\boldsymbol{\eta}(x))_{j^{+}}).

Proof.

𝜽j=(𝜼2)j−(𝜼1)j=(𝜼2)j−(𝜼2)B−j+1=−((𝜼2)B−j+1−(𝜼1)j)=−𝜽B−j+1.subscript𝜽𝑗subscriptsubscript𝜼2𝑗subscriptsubscript𝜼1𝑗subscriptsubscript𝜼2𝑗subscriptsubscript𝜼2𝐵𝑗1subscriptsubscript𝜼2𝐵𝑗1subscriptsubscript𝜼1𝑗subscript𝜽𝐵𝑗1\boldsymbol{\theta}_{j}=(\boldsymbol{\eta}_{2})_{j}-(\boldsymbol{\eta}_{1})_{j}=(\boldsymbol{\eta}_{2})_{j}-(\boldsymbol{\eta}_{2})_{B-j+1}=-((\boldsymbol{\eta}_{2})_{B-j+1}-(\boldsymbol{\eta}_{1})_{j})=-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{B-j+1}.

Algorithm.

Appendix D Additional Results

The budget parameter b𝑏b controls how many bits the I-MVU mechanism outputs. We performed ablation study on b𝑏b to show that for the sample-level DP experiment in Section 4.2, I-MVU with b=1𝑏1b=1 achieves nearly the same privacy-utility trade-off as with b=2,3,4𝑏234b=2,3,4. Figure 6 shows the global model’s test accuracy vs. DP ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon for the Gaussian mechanism and I-MVU with b=1,2,3,4𝑏1234b=1,2,3,4. Evidently, increasing b𝑏b from 1 to 4 does not result in a significant increase in test accuracy for a fixed value of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. This can be contrasted with the result in Figure 4, where increasing b𝑏b from 1 to 4 does result in a significant boost in test accuracy.
